issue.title: Create unique URLs to prevent people from registering any number

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body: Right now people can register any number by manually typing the authorize URL with the right query string. This can be fixed by creating long, randomly generated URLs (much like email verification URLs) to send to registering users.

issue.title: A security measure needs to be added

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body: Right now, as long as you have the phone number of a user, you can access their contacts. We need to implement a security measure such as the polynomial function that we discussed.

issue.title: Validate and standardize the user's phone number

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body:
In `sms.py`, there is a comment that reads:
```python
# Add checks to ensure phone_number is standardized
```

Currently, users can put any word or number as their phone number and the application will accept it and record it in the database. We need to verify that what the user gave was a phone number, and we need to standardize it into a format with 10 numbers (no plus sign, dashes or parens). 

Possible formats for phone numbers that the user could submit:

`Helloworld` This needs to be replied with an error.
`(123) 456-7890` This would be read as "(123)" because we split the message by spaces.
`123-456-7890` Need to remove dashes.
`+11234567890` National format. Need to remove the first two characters.
`1234567890` This is the format all the other formats will be converted to.

issue.title: A security measure needs to be added

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body: Right now, as long as you have the phone number of a user, you can access their contacts. We need to implement a security measure such as the polynomial function that we discussed.

issue.title: The authorization success page is ugly

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body:
It is almost unreadable on mobile. Let's make it look pretty. It needs to change to give users a brief tutorial on how to use the service they just signed up for.

Here is an example of what it should say:
> Authentication success! You are ready to use lost-n-phoned to get your contacts' phone numbers. Simply text (from any phone) your phone number, followed by the name of the person whose phone number you want to find, to our number [our Twilio number here].
Example: "123-456-7890 John Smith" to 098-765-4321

issue.title: Bad reply to sending your number as an authorized user with no query
issue.body: If the query is nothing and the user is authorized, we need to reply with an error message. Currently, the server replies with "Contact not found."

issue.title: Bad reply to sending your number as an authorized user with no query
issue.body: If the query is nothing and the user is authorized, we need to reply with an error message. Currently, the server replies with "Contact not found."

issue.title: Make Lost and Phoned useful to others

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body:
Steps to prepare Lost and Phoned for public use:
- [x] Update readme with the story behind the repository and note that it was Bala's idea
- [x] Fix code so that Google contacts are returned properly
- [x] Add to the code the ability to refresh tokens for long-term use
- [x] Write documentation in the wiki for how to set up the server
- [x] Write documentation in the wiki for how to set up the database

Important links:
https://console.developers.google.com/apis/credentials?project=lost-n-phone
https://developers.google.com/people/v1/libraries
http://google-auth-oauthlib.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html
https://developers.google.com/actions/identity/oauth2-code-flow
https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OAuth2
https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OAuth2WebServer

issue.title: Validate and standardize the user's phone number

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body:
In `sms.py`, there is a comment that reads:
```python
# Add checks to ensure phone_number is standardized
```

Currently, users can put any word or number as their phone number and the application will accept it and record it in the database. We need to verify that what the user gave was a phone number, and we need to standardize it into a format with 10 numbers (no plus sign, dashes or parens). 

Possible formats for phone numbers that the user could submit:

`Helloworld` This needs to be replied with an error.
`(123) 456-7890` This would be read as "(123)" because we split the message by spaces.
`123-456-7890` Need to remove dashes.
`+11234567890` National format. Need to remove the first two characters.
`1234567890` This is the format all the other formats will be converted to.

issue.title: A JSON save file is not safe for simultaneous read/writes

milestone.description: Get the repo production-ready so it can be deployed for a 6 month testing period.

issue.body:
I do not have a complete understanding of how Flask's application and request contexts work, but it seems to me that the current method of storing user data in a JSON file is unsafe. Different simultaneous request contexts may have different savefile dicts, which will cause problems. 

For example:
While the savefile dictionary is loaded in one request context, another request context may save its savefile dictionary to the file. This updated information will be promptly overwritten by the former request context once it saves its savefile dict (which has not been kept up to date). 

Perhaps Flask does not run functions at the same time. Regardless, it is still better to use a database, which will always be up to date with the latest changes with no risk of data loss.

issue.title: Database integration
issue.body: The structure and names of the database have been changed from what they were during the hackathon. In `sms.py`, the JSON method of saving data has been entirely replaced by integration with the MySQL database. In `sql.py`, the code has been cleaned up. Also, functions have been changed because the database stores more credential data than just the token. New functions have been added for updating and removing users.

issue.title: Not all contacts whose names exactly match the query are returned
issue.body: The `exact_matches` dict will have the same key for all contacts with the same name. Instead of a dict, a list of sets should be used.
